data.title: Queertoons The dynamics of same-sex desire in animated cartoons
data.meta_description: Queertoons The dynamics of same-sex desire in animated cartoons
data.text:
The study presented is a comparative investigation into multimodal discourses (O’Halloran, Tan, Smith & Podlasov, 2011) of same-sex relationships and desire in The Simpsons and Steven Universe. Analysis is applied to 15 key episodes in order to examine the way in which same-sex, or non-heterosexual romantic desire and relationships are presented in an aging and more recent animated TV show, commonly viewed by both adults as well as children; this is done in order to examine the ways in which homosexuality is routinely presented in each. Analysis adopts a Foucauldian interpretive approach to language (Arribas-Ayllon & Walkerdine, 2008) alongside other multimodal aspects of discourse (e.g. imagery; sound) in order to analyse constructions and representations of gay relationships and desire and how they are situated within the shows. Findings suggest that while The Simpsons adheres to the standard reproduction of prejudicial, stereotyped and marginalising discourses, Steven Universe takes a more unique and emotionally orientated approached to the constructions of discourses involving same-sex relationships and desire and that the progression of gay visibility in cartoons is only now extending beyond fleeting, two-dimensional stereotypes towards more intimate and romanticised discourses of same-sex relationships and desire.

Presented at the Midwest PCA/ACA conference in October 2017, and also published in a longer form in the Fall 2017 issue of Red Feather Journal. Children’s animation remains a highly contested space, under great scrutiny due to its presumed importance in forming the identities of children. As a result, queerness (in all its forms) has long been relegated to mere connotation through subtext. More recently, however, a shift has been made with series such as The Legend of Korra and Steven Universe, which are more explicit in their denotative expressions of queer identity. What role does oppositional queer reading, primarily as understood by Alex Doty, play in this evolution? This paper argues that nonheterocentrist interpretations of children’s animation has destabilized our understanding of media intended for children, and that this alteration may be due in some part to the ability of fandoms to influence the creators of this media.

ABSTRACT This article studies the representation of queer characters and themes in the contemporary adult animated sitcom. We argue that even though popular culture is often assumed to reiterate and consolidate the discourse of heteronormativity, adult animated sitcoms create space for queer resistance. Since the genre draws on postmodern strategies of representation, we argue that queer resistance is subversively articulated through instances of pastiche and parody. It is embedded in content that is both complicit with and critical of the heteronormal. Through a textual thematic analysis of Family Guy, this case study illustrates how postmodern textual strategies create deconstructionist instances that expose and subvert the hegemony of heteronormativity.
